elements.text: [Part One]
Sector eight alert. Sector eight alert. Unauthorised capsule entry imminent. Repeat, unauthorised capsule entry imminent. Stat two on sector eight.
A Tardis materialises. A door opens and closes. Footsteps.
It's a Type 70 time capsule, registration code negative. It could be stolen. Stasers at the ready. Stay where you are. Identify yourself.
Commander, my name is Vansell, Celestial Intervention Agency. Take me to the President of the Time Lords immediately.
The President has declared Gallifrey under a state of emergency. You can go
I know that. That's why I'm here, you idiot.
My orders are to let no one
If you obey your orders, Commander, you'll be signing the death warrant of the Time Lords.
This way, sir.

These holographic images are being relayed from observation posts across Gallifrey. This fleet has been massing around the planet for some time now. The sky is black with their ships. And you are saying that despite all our powers, we are helpless, Vansell?
I am, Lord President.
But the transduction barrier
Will not stop them, whoever they are. They have a technology beyond our understanding, and it's clear they mean to destroy us.
This is inconceivable.

Their control of the space-time continuum is virtually absolute. All time capsules and time rings have been rendered useless. We made special adaptations to the core of my Tardis just to get me here. I don't know how long it will remain operational.
Who are they?
We simply don't know. They refused all our attempts at communication.
How can this have happened without our knowing?
We're not sure. It's clear that there's been some distortion of established historical patterns. And we do have one clue.
Which is?
Before our monitoring posts were destroyed, we detected faint traces of a Time Lord's artron energy embedded in the time distortion.
A Time Lord's artron? Have you identified the Time Lord to whom this artron energy belongs?
The Doctor.
Console beeps. The Seventh Doctor speaks.
Mmm. That seems to be matching up nicely. Yes. Steady, old girl. Steady. Don't get overexcited.
Cloister bell tolls.
The Cloister bell? Oh no.
Wordless singing.
Who? Who is that? I think I should change the coordinates. That's better.
The Tardis materialises.
Why did I do that?
[OC]: Doctor. Doctor? Doctor.
Time Lords?
[OC]: Doctor, there is very little time. You must (static)
Look, if you're going to interfere in my life again, the least you could do was get a decent phone line. Now, speak up!
[OC]: Please, Doctor, listen. Imperative that you
Transmission lost.
What was all that about? He didn't look too happy. That sound again. Seems to be coming from outside. It seems safe enough. Only one thing to do. Step outside.
Door opens.
Should have brought my pith helmet.
Laughs. A woman's distant cry for help.
Someone in trouble?
[OC]: Help! Somebody, please!
Hello? Where are you?
[OC]: Oh, my God. Quickly, over here.
Keep shouting. I can't see you. I'm following your voice.
[OC]: Okay, I'll just, er, who are you?
A friend. Oh, I need something sharper than an umbrella to hack through this. Keep shouting.
[OC]: Hurry up, for God's sake! I'm sinking!
Sinking? Quicksand. A bog or something. Don't struggle! Do you hear me?
Running through foliage.
What's your name?
[OC]: (coughs) What?
Your name! Tell me your name!
[OC]: Elenya.
All right, Elenya. I still can't see you. It's too dark. But you're sounding very close now. Listen to me. You mustn't struggle. Do you understand?
[OC]: What's your name?
I'm the Doctor. I er
Doc!
An old hag's cackling laugh.
You're not a lady, I take it?
Doc!
[OC]: Doctor! Doctor, is that you? Hurry up, please.
Do you know where the girl is? The girl!
The girl?
Yes, yes, the girl. Can you show me where she is? Take me to her. She's in trouble.
Doctor, your girl?
Yes, girl.
She dead soon.
Out of my way.
You find your girl, you die too, Doctor. (cackles)
Oh my God, oh my God. Oh, Doctor. Doctor, please. Please.
You'd be Elenya, I take it? Don't bother shaking my hand, just grab my umbrella instead.
I can't, can't reach it.
Yes, you can. Try again. That's it. (neaves) Come on. How long were you in there?
Oh, I don't know. Long enough to go numb. Hours, I think.
Why didn't she try and rescue you?
She? I didn't see anyone.
I think she was a female. A creature of some kind. Come on, night's drawing in, and you need some dry clothes. I'll take you to my ship.
Metal squeaking.
Damned wheelchair. Why the old bag can't oil me wheels I don't know.
Cackling approaches.
Ah, the light of my life returns. Who was it, friends of yours?
To bed with you, Sancroff.
But I do so enjoy our little chats, Ruthley. Some may call it spitting, belching and passing wind, but to me your every utterance is simply music to the ears.

(spits) My job to keep you alive, Sancroff. My job change your stained sheets, carry you to bathroom, make your food. My job. Every day I like my job less and less. One day I forget to do it at all, maybe, and you drown in your own filth, old man.
You left out the bit about wiping my bottom, you old charmer. (laughs sadly) Oh, dear.
Muttering and tapping keyboard.
[OC]: Report, Ruthley. Is the prisoner well?
All is well, Commandant.
[OC]: Good. Our long-range scans picked up some ion trails in your sector. You haven't had any visitors, have you?
Ha! No visitors. No way through the shield. All alone here.
That's what we like to hear. You keep your nose clean, Ruthley. Remember, you've only got a couple more years to serve, there's a good girl. Command out.
Good girl. Pah. Your slave, but I'll be free sooner than you think.
Come on.
Are we there yet?
Yes. Ah, this is it. Now, let me just get my key.
Er, is that your ship?
Appearances can be deceptive.
Key rattles against lock.
Oh.
What's the matter?
It er, it won't open.
Thumps on door.
I don't understand. It's as if some force is shutting me out from the interior dimensions.
What do you mean?
Here, take my coat. It's really quite dark now. It's probably going to get a lot colder, and you're in shock.
What a way to end a geology field trip, dying of exposure.
You're far from death yet, Elenya. How did you get here in the first place anyway?
Why are you looking at me like that?
Forgive me. There's something about you. Have we met before?
No, I don't think so. I was in a crash. They all died.
Who all died?
My friends, the pilot, my favourite tutor, Janice. I should have died with them, but I was in the deep freeze storing specimens when it happened. Must have protected me.
What happened?

This planet wasn't on the charts. We came across it by accident. It was shielded from detection somehow. We just happened to be pulled off course by its gravity. They were going in fora closer orbit when I went into the deep freeze. I heard the pilot on the intercom, said something about an atmospheric disruption. What about you?

I received a warning from my people. And I heard something calling. And now I'm locked out of my own Tardis. Oh, never mind me. We've got to find you some shelter. That creature, that woman must live somewhere near here. We've got to find some civilisation. Come on.
Distant engines whoosh overhead.
Another ship.
Boom!
What is going on here?
Didn't sound like there'll be any survivors, did it, Doctor?
Come on, Elenya.
Another ship. That's eight this week alone. What's happening? Are your precious shields failing?
Not my shields. Come, bed for you. Up. Oh, you getting fat, old man.
Careful, that was my leg.
You stay in bed all night.
Ruthley, who do you think is sending the ships?
How can I tell? They smash through planet shield, crash, destroyed. No survivors.
But if the shield is failing, perhaps one day
Don't get hopes up, Sancroff. Nobody is putting you out of my misery. Now, sleep.
Leaves muttering.
Sleep. You stupid old baggage, I haven't slept for years.
Ow!
Are you all right?
Yes. No. Oh, I don't know. It's so dark I can't see where I'm going. Oh, I'm being so pathetic.
No, you're not. No, you're not. It's not as if you've twisted your ankle, is it?
Hmm?
Just sit down and rest a moment. Oh no, not on that. Nasty spines.
They laugh.
What now, Doctor?
Oh, well if you'll just excuse me, I think I've an old pair of field glasses in my jacket. Right, sorry, here we are. Yes. Ah, thank you.
Any sign of life? Apart from the sort that wants us for supper.
Er, not that I can see. Wait a minute, yes. Ah, a light. Square. Looks like a window. About a half a mile away, I should say.
Half a? Is that close?
Close enough. Come on.
Engines flying overhead.
Another one.
Boom!
What is this, the planet Suicide?
Or Kamikaze.
What?
Pilots willing to sacrifice their lives for a greater cause.
I don't see any causes to follow around here. Doctor, it's coming this way!
Let's get a move on, shall we?
Transmission increased.
[OC]: Knight to Velyshaa. Knight to Velyshaa. Respond.
Velyshaa responds. Four vessel breaks through shield.

[OC]: Confirmed. Four vessels break through shield. All others destroyed on atmospheric entry. We have lost navigational control on all vessels. Bio-assassin cultures will activate on impact as programmed.
Velyshaa understands Knight. Will do my duty. Out. Now it begins.
That was a little too close for comfort.
Oh, my God. Listen, Doctor. There's another one coming in.
Get down!
Wheee Boom! Fires burning.
Doctor! Doctor!
Here. Are you all right?
Still alive, if that's what you mean. What about you?
Oh, I've lost my bearings completely.
Oh, right in the middle of it all, aren't we? We're going to fry.
Not if I can help it. I think we're heading er, this way.
Oh, looks like what's left of that last ship.
Yes. What's that noise?
Look out!
Thud.
Phwoar, that was close. Still in one piece?
Yeah, yeah. Which is more than I can say for the ship. My God, what is that?
The remains of the crew.
Oh, that could have been me.
Fascinating.
What? Let's get out of here.
I wonder what kind of lifeform it was? Or is?
What do you mean, is? It's dead, or dying.
No. No, no. I rather think it's being born. Look. Mass seems to be enlarging itself.
Creaking.
Doctor!
(mechanical) All security drudgers report fire extinguished.
2: Report logged. Transmitting to control.
[OC]: Have located two surviving humanoids.
Show them to me. Ach! Doctor and pathetic girl. Irrelevant. Kill them.
[OC]: That procedure is not permitted.
Then you follow your procedure, machine.
Transmission ends.
Heh. But matter, all dead soon. (cackles)
This is too much. Robots. Are they from that crashed ship?
No. They couldn't survive that kind of impact. I rather think they're local inhabitants. (loud) Hello! Thank you for
Humanoid lifeforms, you have landed on a security restricted planet. Please surrender all weaponry and identify yourselves.
I don't have any weaponry. Do you?
No. (loud) No, I don't.
Identify yourselves.
I'm Elenya and this is the Doctor.
Much obliged.
My pleasure.
Initiate mind scan.
Mind?
Cries of pain.
Psst. I say.
Hmm? Hello.
Shh. Voice down, old man, or the old pig'll come sniffing. Can't seem to wake the girl. Out cold.
Oof, so was I. How long for?
A few hours, I'd say.
Are we being watched?
What? No. Why?
Then what are you doing hiding down there?
Oh, I see. No, not hiding. I can't walk. Dragged meself from me bedroom. Old bag takes me wheelchair at night.
What happened to us?
I say, you're not frightened of me, are you.
Should I be?
No, no reason at all, old chap. Well, I could hear the Drudgers were up and about, knew we must have visitors. Happens from time to time.
Come on, Elenya, come on. Drudgers? The robots?
Yes, hovering chaps. That's right. They'd have hit you with a mind scan. Probably wanted to know why you're here.
We're both here by accident. I think.
Accident, eh?
(waking) Janice? David?
It's the Doctor.
Doctor?
Oh, I remember.
How are you feeling?
Better, actually. Who's that?
Sancroff. Delighted to make your acquaintance, my dear.
(sotto) Is he friendly?
Seems to be. Mister Sancroff, can we have some light on the proceedings?
Oh, no, no, no, no, old boy. Best to keep it dark, or the old pig
Will come sniffing. I see, yeah. This person you obviously have such an affection for, is she rotund, brutish looking and impolite?
Ah, you've met the lovely Ruthley.
Report, Security Drudger Seven.
[OC]: Have located bio-engineered lifeforms emerging from spacecraft wreckage.
Ruthley cackles.
[OC]: Clarify your response. Control, I do not understand.
You will understand.
Bio-engineered lifeform, you have landed on a security restricted planet. Please surrender all weaponry and identify yourselves.
Open fire.
What the hell was that?
My God.
Sancroff, have you any idea?
No. No, no. I wonder, could you help me you onto the bed? It's getting a bit cold down here.
Yes. Er, Elenya?
Oh yes, sure.
Thank you.
Effort. Door opens.
Ha! You try to escape? Nowhere to go, Sancroff. Nowhere to go. Not even your friends can rescue you.
Rescue? Rescue him from what?
Weapons fire.
That was one of your Drudgers exploding, unless I'm very much mistaken.
(laughs) They kill you, Sancroff. They kill you all.
My God, what have you done, you mad old bitch?
No one weeps for Sancroff.
Door closes.
What does she mean, Sancroff? What has she done?
She's done a deal.
A deal?
I'm a dead man, Doctor. You and Elenya must leave this planet or they'll kill you too. They won't want any witnesses.
We can't get off this planet.
Who? Who will kill us?
Oh, assassins, my dear. Isn't that what they call them?
Whoever they are, they're getting closer.
Door opens.
They come to get Sancroff now. They sniff him out. No need. I go to tell them where you are.
Door closes as she cackles.
Silly old fool. Do you know, sometimes I actually found her tolerable?
We're in trouble, Doctor, aren't we?
Yes. Sancroff, is there somewhere secure in this building? Somewhere where we can hide?
Well, it isn't a very big house. There's Ruthley's room, but it's still probably locked.
Take us there. We'll carry you.
Very well. Turn left.
Bio-engineered lifeforms will halt and disarm. This is your last warning. We will be forced to open fire. All Drudgers open fire.
Weapons fire.
Drudger One to all Security Drudgers. Bio-engineered lifeforms are impervious to our fire- power, and are converging on main building. Retreat. Retreat. Retreat.
Come on.
Sorry to be a nuisance. I'm not as svelte as I used to be. Ah, here it is. Oh my, we're there. Good God, it's open! She must be confident, silly old cow.
In here?
Effort.
Ah, my chair. Put me down.
Look at all this security equipment. What's it all for?
Well, that's the door locked.
Oh, I don't expect it will hold.
Sancroff, will you please tell us what is going on? Why does Ruthley want you dead?
She doesn't. At least, I don't think it's personal. No, she's just done a deal.
What sort of deal? Why is this a security restricted planet?
And what planet is it? Why was it hidden?
Because it doesn't exist, officially, and it certainly has no name. Probably did once, or maybe it was just some kind of mistake of classification.
Yes, all right, all right. Who is attacking us?
Doctor, I've got a picture on one of these monitors. I think this is what we're up against.
[OC]: At last you are here. I did my job, yes? I did my job well, yes?
I deliver into your hands the infamous Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa. And now, Ruthley is free, yes?
There must be no witnesses.
You silly, stupid old Ruthley.
Weapon fires. Ruthley screams.
First Knight of Velyshaa? What does that mean, Sancroff?
Someone I once was. Another lifetime. The reason I'm here.

Surveillance systems. Drudger controls. Maintenance. We've got to find a way of defending ourselves. Those creatures intend to kill us all. Short range shield emitters. Wait a minute. Perhaps I could? Yes, reroute the power of the planetary shields through the short range emitters.
You mean you could make this room impregnable?
Not just that, Elenya. The resultant power overload would be, well, I mean, it would be absolutely
Sorry to drag you into this, old man.
Banging on door.
They've found us! I've got them on the screen again, Doctor.
[OC]: Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa, hear this decree recorded into my bio-matrix by the elected citizens of Calfador.
Oh yes, I remember them well.
I don't like the sound of this.

[OC]: Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa, though it was the majority judgement of the War Crimes Tribunal that your sentence was to be eternal banishment, we have always considered your continued existence a moral abhorrence. Revenge is the only antidote to the suffering you inflicted. And now our search for you is over. For the sake of our Alliance, those allies must never know that it is we who strike you down in the name of all that is good in the universe. Surrender yourself for execution.
Sancroff! You're some kind of
War criminal. A long time ago, my dear. A lifetime ago.
There must be some way of talking to these ah! Hello? Listen to me. We're here by accident, but perhaps
[OC]: Citizens of Calfador
Have no quarrel with you, but we regret there must be no witnesses.
Opens fire.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
TANNOY: Sector eight alert. Sector eight alert. Unauthorised capsule entry imminent. Repeat, unauthorised capsule entry imminent. Stat two on sector eight.
RALDETH: It's a Type 70 time capsule, registration code negative. It could be stolen. Stasers at the ready. Stay where you are. Identify yourself.
VANSELL: Commander, my name is Vansell, Celestial Intervention Agency. Take me to the President of the Time Lords immediately.
RALDETH: The President has declared Gallifrey under a state of emergency. You can go
VANSELL: I know that. That's why I'm here, you idiot.
RALDETH: My orders are to let no one
VANSELL: If you obey your orders, Commander, you'll be signing the death warrant of the Time Lords.
RALDETH: This way, sir.
PRESIDENT: These holographic images are being relayed from observation posts across Gallifrey. This fleet has been massing around the planet for some time now. The sky is black with their ships. And you are saying that despite all our powers, we are helpless, Vansell?
VANSELL: I am, Lord President.
PRESIDENT: But the transduction barrier
VANSELL: Will not stop them, whoever they are. They have a technology beyond our understanding, and it's clear they mean to destroy us.
PRESIDENT: This is inconceivable.
VANSELL: Their control of the space-time continuum is virtually absolute. All time capsules and time rings have been rendered useless. We made special adaptations to the core of my Tardis just to get me here. I don't know how long it will remain operational.
PRESIDENT: Who are they?
VANSELL: We simply don't know. They refused all our attempts at communication.
PRESIDENT: How can this have happened without our knowing?
VANSELL: We're not sure. It's clear that there's been some distortion of established historical patterns. And we do have one clue.
PRESIDENT: Which is?
VANSELL: Before our monitoring posts were destroyed, we detected faint traces of a Time Lord's artron energy embedded in the time distortion.
PRESIDENT: A Time Lord's artron? Have you identified the Time Lord to whom this artron energy belongs?
VANSELL: The Doctor.
DOCTOR: Mmm. That seems to be matching up nicely. Yes. Steady, old girl. Steady. Don't get overexcited.
DOCTOR: The Cloister bell? Oh no.
DOCTOR: Who? Who is that? I think I should change the coordinates. That's better.
DOCTOR: Why did I do that?
PRESIDENT: [OC]: Doctor. Doctor? Doctor.
DOCTOR: Time Lords?
PRESIDENT: [OC]: Doctor, there is very little time. You must (static)
DOCTOR: Look, if you're going to interfere in my life again, the least you could do was get a decent phone line. Now, speak up!
PRESIDENT: [OC]: Please, Doctor, listen. Imperative that you
DOCTOR: What was all that about? He didn't look too happy. That sound again. Seems to be coming from outside. It seems safe enough. Only one thing to do. Step outside.
DOCTOR: Should have brought my pith helmet.
DOCTOR: Someone in trouble?
ELENYA: [OC]: Help! Somebody, please!
DOCTOR: Hello? Where are you?
ELENYA: [OC]: Oh, my God. Quickly, over here.
DOCTOR: Keep shouting. I can't see you. I'm following your voice.
ELENYA: [OC]: Okay, I'll just, er, who are you?
DOCTOR: A friend. Oh, I need something sharper than an umbrella to hack through this. Keep shouting.
ELENYA: [OC]: Hurry up, for God's sake! I'm sinking!
DOCTOR: Sinking? Quicksand. A bog or something. Don't struggle! Do you hear me?
DOCTOR: What's your name?
ELENYA: [OC]: (coughs) What?
DOCTOR: Your name! Tell me your name!
ELENYA: [OC]: Elenya.
DOCTOR: All right, Elenya. I still can't see you. It's too dark. But you're sounding very close now. Listen to me. You mustn't struggle. Do you understand?
ELENYA: [OC]: What's your name?
DOCTOR: I'm the Doctor. I er
RUTHLEY: Doc!
DOCTOR: You're not a lady, I take it?
RUTHLEY: Doc!
ELENYA: [OC]: Doctor! Doctor, is that you? Hurry up, please.
DOCTOR: Do you know where the girl is? The girl!
RUTHLEY: The girl?
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, the girl. Can you show me where she is? Take me to her. She's in trouble.
RUTHLEY: Doctor, your girl?
DOCTOR: Yes, girl.
RUTHLEY: She dead soon.
DOCTOR: Out of my way.
RUTHLEY: You find your girl, you die too, Doctor. (cackles)
ELENYA: Oh my God, oh my God. Oh, Doctor. Doctor, please. Please.
DOCTOR: You'd be Elenya, I take it? Don't bother shaking my hand, just grab my umbrella instead.
ELENYA: I can't, can't reach it.
DOCTOR: Yes, you can. Try again. That's it. (neaves) Come on. How long were you in there?
ELENYA: Oh, I don't know. Long enough to go numb. Hours, I think.
DOCTOR: Why didn't she try and rescue you?
ELENYA: She? I didn't see anyone.
DOCTOR: I think she was a female. A creature of some kind. Come on, night's drawing in, and you need some dry clothes. I'll take you to my ship.
SANCROFF: Damned wheelchair. Why the old bag can't oil me wheels I don't know.
SANCROFF: Ah, the light of my life returns. Who was it, friends of yours?
RUTHLEY: To bed with you, Sancroff.
SANCROFF: But I do so enjoy our little chats, Ruthley. Some may call it spitting, belching and passing wind, but to me your every utterance is simply music to the ears.
RUTHLEY: (spits) My job to keep you alive, Sancroff. My job change your stained sheets, carry you to bathroom, make your food. My job. Every day I like my job less and less. One day I forget to do it at all, maybe, and you drown in your own filth, old man.
SANCROFF: You left out the bit about wiping my bottom, you old charmer. (laughs sadly) Oh, dear.
COMMANDANT: [OC]: Report, Ruthley. Is the prisoner well?
RUTHLEY: All is well, Commandant.
COMMANDANT: [OC]: Good. Our long-range scans picked up some ion trails in your sector. You haven't had any visitors, have you?
RUTHLEY: Ha! No visitors. No way through the shield. All alone here.
COMMANDANT: That's what we like to hear. You keep your nose clean, Ruthley. Remember, you've only got a couple more years to serve, there's a good girl. Command out.
RUTHLEY: Good girl. Pah. Your slave, but I'll be free sooner than you think.
DOCTOR: Come on.
ELENYA: Are we there yet?
DOCTOR: Yes. Ah, this is it. Now, let me just get my key.
ELENYA: Er, is that your ship?
DOCTOR: Appearances can be deceptive.
DOCTOR: Oh.
ELENYA: What's the matter?
DOCTOR: It er, it won't open.
DOCTOR: I don't understand. It's as if some force is shutting me out from the interior dimensions.
ELENYA: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: Here, take my coat. It's really quite dark now. It's probably going to get a lot colder, and you're in shock.
ELENYA: What a way to end a geology field trip, dying of exposure.
DOCTOR: You're far from death yet, Elenya. How did you get here in the first place anyway?
ELENYA: Why are you looking at me like that?
DOCTOR: Forgive me. There's something about you. Have we met before?
ELENYA: No, I don't think so. I was in a crash. They all died.
DOCTOR: Who all died?
ELENYA: My friends, the pilot, my favourite tutor, Janice. I should have died with them, but I was in the deep freeze storing specimens when it happened. Must have protected me.
DOCTOR: What happened?
ELENYA: This planet wasn't on the charts. We came across it by accident. It was shielded from detection somehow. We just happened to be pulled off course by its gravity. They were going in fora closer orbit when I went into the deep freeze. I heard the pilot on the intercom, said something about an atmospheric disruption. What about you?
DOCTOR: I received a warning from my people. And I heard something calling. And now I'm locked out of my own Tardis. Oh, never mind me. We've got to find you some shelter. That creature, that woman must live somewhere near here. We've got to find some civilisation. Come on.
ELENYA: Another ship.
DOCTOR: What is going on here?
ELENYA: Didn't sound like there'll be any survivors, did it, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Come on, Elenya.
SANCROFF: Another ship. That's eight this week alone. What's happening? Are your precious shields failing?
RUTHLEY: Not my shields. Come, bed for you. Up. Oh, you getting fat, old man.
SANCROFF: Careful, that was my leg.
RUTHLEY: You stay in bed all night.
SANCROFF: Ruthley, who do you think is sending the ships?
RUTHLEY: How can I tell? They smash through planet shield, crash, destroyed. No survivors.
SANCROFF: But if the shield is failing, perhaps one day
RUTHLEY: Don't get hopes up, Sancroff. Nobody is putting you out of my misery. Now, sleep.
SANCROFF: Sleep. You stupid old baggage, I haven't slept for years.
ELENYA: Ow!
DOCTOR: Are you all right?
ELENYA: Yes. No. Oh, I don't know. It's so dark I can't see where I'm going. Oh, I'm being so pathetic.
DOCTOR: No, you're not. No, you're not. It's not as if you've twisted your ankle, is it?
ELENYA: Hmm?
DOCTOR: Just sit down and rest a moment. Oh no, not on that. Nasty spines.
ELENYA: What now, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Oh, well if you'll just excuse me, I think I've an old pair of field glasses in my jacket. Right, sorry, here we are. Yes. Ah, thank you.
ELENYA: Any sign of life? Apart from the sort that wants us for supper.
DOCTOR: Er, not that I can see. Wait a minute, yes. Ah, a light. Square. Looks like a window. About a half a mile away, I should say.
ELENYA: Half a? Is that close?
DOCTOR: Close enough. Come on.
ELENYA: Another one.
ELENYA: What is this, the planet Suicide?
DOCTOR: Or Kamikaze.
ELENYA: What?
DOCTOR: Pilots willing to sacrifice their lives for a greater cause.
ELENYA: I don't see any causes to follow around here. Doctor, it's coming this way!
DOCTOR: Let's get a move on, shall we?
RUTHLEY: Transmission increased.
KNIGHT: [OC]: Knight to Velyshaa. Knight to Velyshaa. Respond.
RUTHLEY: Velyshaa responds. Four vessel breaks through shield.
KNIGHT: [OC]: Confirmed. Four vessels break through shield. All others destroyed on atmospheric entry. We have lost navigational control on all vessels. Bio-assassin cultures will activate on impact as programmed.
RUTHLEY: Velyshaa understands Knight. Will do my duty. Out. Now it begins.
DOCTOR: That was a little too close for comfort.
ELENYA: Oh, my God. Listen, Doctor. There's another one coming in.
DOCTOR: Get down!
ELENYA: Doctor! Doctor!
DOCTOR: Here. Are you all right?
ELENYA: Still alive, if that's what you mean. What about you?
DOCTOR: Oh, I've lost my bearings completely.
ELENYA: Oh, right in the middle of it all, aren't we? We're going to fry.
DOCTOR: Not if I can help it. I think we're heading er, this way.
ELENYA: Oh, looks like what's left of that last ship.
DOCTOR: Yes. What's that noise?
ELENYA: Look out!
DOCTOR: Phwoar, that was close. Still in one piece?
ELENYA: Yeah, yeah. Which is more than I can say for the ship. My God, what is that?
DOCTOR: The remains of the crew.
ELENYA: Oh, that could have been me.
DOCTOR: Fascinating.
ELENYA: What? Let's get out of here.
DOCTOR: I wonder what kind of lifeform it was? Or is?
ELENYA: What do you mean, is? It's dead, or dying.
DOCTOR: No. No, no. I rather think it's being born. Look. Mass seems to be enlarging itself.
ELENYA: Doctor!
DRUDGER: (mechanical) All security drudgers report fire extinguished.
DRUDGER: 2: Report logged. Transmitting to control.
DRUDGER: [OC]: Have located two surviving humanoids.
RUTHLEY: Show them to me. Ach! Doctor and pathetic girl. Irrelevant. Kill them.
DRUDGER: [OC]: That procedure is not permitted.
RUTHLEY: Then you follow your procedure, machine.
RUTHLEY: Heh. But matter, all dead soon. (cackles)
ELENYA: This is too much. Robots. Are they from that crashed ship?
DOCTOR: No. They couldn't survive that kind of impact. I rather think they're local inhabitants. (loud) Hello! Thank you for
DRUDGER: Humanoid lifeforms, you have landed on a security restricted planet. Please surrender all weaponry and identify yourselves.
DOCTOR: I don't have any weaponry. Do you?
ELENYA: No. (loud) No, I don't.
DRUDGER: Identify yourselves.
ELENYA: I'm Elenya and this is the Doctor.
DOCTOR: Much obliged.
ELENYA: My pleasure.
DRUDGER: Initiate mind scan.
DOCTOR: Mind?
SANCROFF: Psst. I say.
DOCTOR: Hmm? Hello.
SANCROFF: Shh. Voice down, old man, or the old pig'll come sniffing. Can't seem to wake the girl. Out cold.
DOCTOR: Oof, so was I. How long for?
SANCROFF: A few hours, I'd say.
DOCTOR: Are we being watched?
SANCROFF: What? No. Why?
DOCTOR: Then what are you doing hiding down there?
SANCROFF: Oh, I see. No, not hiding. I can't walk. Dragged meself from me bedroom. Old bag takes me wheelchair at night.
DOCTOR: What happened to us?
SANCROFF: I say, you're not frightened of me, are you.
DOCTOR: Should I be?
SANCROFF: No, no reason at all, old chap. Well, I could hear the Drudgers were up and about, knew we must have visitors. Happens from time to time.
DOCTOR: Come on, Elenya, come on. Drudgers? The robots?
SANCROFF: Yes, hovering chaps. That's right. They'd have hit you with a mind scan. Probably wanted to know why you're here.
DOCTOR: We're both here by accident. I think.
SANCROFF: Accident, eh?
ELENYA: (waking) Janice? David?
DOCTOR: It's the Doctor.
SANCROFF: Doctor?
ELENYA: Oh, I remember.
DOCTOR: How are you feeling?
ELENYA: Better, actually. Who's that?
SANCROFF: Sancroff. Delighted to make your acquaintance, my dear.
ELENYA: (sotto) Is he friendly?
DOCTOR: Seems to be. Mister Sancroff, can we have some light on the proceedings?
SANCROFF: Oh, no, no, no, no, old boy. Best to keep it dark, or the old pig
DOCTOR: Will come sniffing. I see, yeah. This person you obviously have such an affection for, is she rotund, brutish looking and impolite?
SANCROFF: Ah, you've met the lovely Ruthley.
RUTHLEY: Report, Security Drudger Seven.
DRUDGER: [OC]: Have located bio-engineered lifeforms emerging from spacecraft wreckage.
DRUDGER: [OC]: Clarify your response. Control, I do not understand.
RUTHLEY: You will understand.
DRUDGER: Bio-engineered lifeform, you have landed on a security restricted planet. Please surrender all weaponry and identify yourselves.
KNIGHT: Open fire.
ELENYA: What the hell was that?
SANCROFF: My God.
DOCTOR: Sancroff, have you any idea?
SANCROFF: No. No, no. I wonder, could you help me you onto the bed? It's getting a bit cold down here.
DOCTOR: Yes. Er, Elenya?
ELENYA: Oh yes, sure.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
RUTHLEY: Ha! You try to escape? Nowhere to go, Sancroff. Nowhere to go. Not even your friends can rescue you.
ELENYA: Rescue? Rescue him from what?
DOCTOR: That was one of your Drudgers exploding, unless I'm very much mistaken.
RUTHLEY: (laughs) They kill you, Sancroff. They kill you all.
SANCROFF: My God, what have you done, you mad old bitch?
RUTHLEY: No one weeps for Sancroff.
DOCTOR: What does she mean, Sancroff? What has she done?
SANCROFF: She's done a deal.
DOCTOR: A deal?
SANCROFF: I'm a dead man, Doctor. You and Elenya must leave this planet or they'll kill you too. They won't want any witnesses.
DOCTOR: We can't get off this planet.
ELENYA: Who? Who will kill us?
SANCROFF: Oh, assassins, my dear. Isn't that what they call them?
DOCTOR: Whoever they are, they're getting closer.
RUTHLEY: They come to get Sancroff now. They sniff him out. No need. I go to tell them where you are.
SANCROFF: Silly old fool. Do you know, sometimes I actually found her tolerable?
ELENYA: We're in trouble, Doctor, aren't we?
DOCTOR: Yes. Sancroff, is there somewhere secure in this building? Somewhere where we can hide?
SANCROFF: Well, it isn't a very big house. There's Ruthley's room, but it's still probably locked.
ELENYA: Take us there. We'll carry you.
SANCROFF: Very well. Turn left.
DRUDGER: Bio-engineered lifeforms will halt and disarm. This is your last warning. We will be forced to open fire. All Drudgers open fire.
DRUDGER: Drudger One to all Security Drudgers. Bio-engineered lifeforms are impervious to our fire- power, and are converging on main building. Retreat. Retreat. Retreat.
ELENYA: Come on.
SANCROFF: Sorry to be a nuisance. I'm not as svelte as I used to be. Ah, here it is. Oh my, we're there. Good God, it's open! She must be confident, silly old cow.
DOCTOR: In here?
SANCROFF: Ah, my chair. Put me down.
ELENYA: Look at all this security equipment. What's it all for?
DOCTOR: Well, that's the door locked.
SANCROFF: Oh, I don't expect it will hold.
DOCTOR: Sancroff, will you please tell us what is going on? Why does Ruthley want you dead?
SANCROFF: She doesn't. At least, I don't think it's personal. No, she's just done a deal.
DOCTOR: What sort of deal? Why is this a security restricted planet?
ELENYA: And what planet is it? Why was it hidden?
SANCROFF: Because it doesn't exist, officially, and it certainly has no name. Probably did once, or maybe it was just some kind of mistake of classification.
DOCTOR: Yes, all right, all right. Who is attacking us?
ELENYA: Doctor, I've got a picture on one of these monitors. I think this is what we're up against.
RUTHLEY: [OC]: At last you are here. I did my job, yes? I did my job well, yes?
RUTHLEY: I deliver into your hands the infamous Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa. And now, Ruthley is free, yes?
ASSASSIN: There must be no witnesses.
SANCROFF: You silly, stupid old Ruthley.
ELENYA: First Knight of Velyshaa? What does that mean, Sancroff?
SANCROFF: Someone I once was. Another lifetime. The reason I'm here.
DOCTOR: Surveillance systems. Drudger controls. Maintenance. We've got to find a way of defending ourselves. Those creatures intend to kill us all. Short range shield emitters. Wait a minute. Perhaps I could? Yes, reroute the power of the planetary shields through the short range emitters.
ELENYA: You mean you could make this room impregnable?
DOCTOR: Not just that, Elenya. The resultant power overload would be, well, I mean, it would be absolutely
SANCROFF: Sorry to drag you into this, old man.
ELENYA: They've found us! I've got them on the screen again, Doctor.
ASSASSIN: [OC]: Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa, hear this decree recorded into my bio-matrix by the elected citizens of Calfador.
SANCROFF: Oh yes, I remember them well.
DOCTOR: I don't like the sound of this.
CITIZEN: [OC]: Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa, though it was the majority judgement of the War Crimes Tribunal that your sentence was to be eternal banishment, we have always considered your continued existence a moral abhorrence. Revenge is the only antidote to the suffering you inflicted. And now our search for you is over. For the sake of our Alliance, those allies must never know that it is we who strike you down in the name of all that is good in the universe. Surrender yourself for execution.
ELENYA: Sancroff! You're some kind of
SANCROFF: War criminal. A long time ago, my dear. A lifetime ago.
DOCTOR: There must be some way of talking to these ah! Hello? Listen to me. We're here by accident, but perhaps
ASSASSIN: [OC]: Citizens of Calfador
ASSASSIN: Have no quarrel with you, but we regret there must be no witnesses.

elements.text: [Part Two]
On a real historical German U-boat. Look her and her Captain up online.
Periscope depth, Captain.
Up periscope. Now, let us see if it is safe to surface and recharge our batteries, if only to stop the bleeding of Mister Hersh.
I could do with the fresh air myself, Captain.
And miss the foul stench down here? I thought you loved your country, Rudi. Looks as if the weather is favourable for a change. Ah!
What is it?
A merchantman.
Move to torpedo range?
No. Take a look for yourself. What tonnage would you estimate, Rudi?
Five, maybe six thousand?
Mmm, I concur. Maybe not worth wasting the torpedo. We go in for a closer look, ja?
Ja.
Helm, thirty degrees starboard. Full ahead.
Thirty degrees starboard. Full ahead.
She's flying the British flag.
Which means her Captain is either very bold or very stupid.
(A ship's bell rings eight bells as the Tardis materialises. The door opens and the Fifth Doctor steps out into the SS Centurion.)

Hmm. Just as I thought. A sea vessel of some sort. Probably steam turbines. Come on out, you two. Let's stretch your sea legs, while I use my tracker to see if this is where that time distortion or whatever it was is coming from.
Beeps.
Hello. This looks promising. Or not, as the case may be.
Walks, opens door.
Definitely coming from this direction. Ah. I thought so. A tear in the fabric of Time.
[OC]: Doctor, Doctor, Doctor, Doctor.
Who is that?
[OC]: (echoing) Doctor, listen to me.
The Time Lords?
[OC]: Yes. Doctor, you must
I can't hear you. Say it again.
[OC]: Must return. The Tardis.
What? What do you mean?
[OC]: Time is running out. The Tardis. You understand.
Frankly, no. Return the Tardis? Is that what you're saying? Return it to Gallifrey?
[OC]: No. To the Tardis.
What's causing this distortion? Perhaps I can help.
[OC]: Return to the Tardis.
Why?
[OC]: Please, Doctor.
All right, all right. Then what?
[OC]: Leave. The destruction of. Time.
Destruction of Time? Well, questions can wait. Mine is not to reason why, mine is but to get back in the Tardis and. Locked.
Key rattles against the lock.
No good. Tegan! Turlough! Can you hear me? Open the door!
Siren song.
What was that?
(a Liver bird) Who are you talking to?
Ah, hello. Where did you spring from?
And just who the hell are you, for that matter.
Well, er, Turlough! Tegan!
Thumps Tardis door.
I think perhaps you should come and see the Captain.
I don't think we need to bother
I think perhaps I should call for me friend Dan. You won't like him much. He's got much bigger muscles than me.
Has he indeed? Look, you couldn't just forget you'd seen me?
(laughs) You're a cheeky one and no mistake.
Crash!
Must be a ruddy Hun U-boat!
Turlough! Tegan! What's the matter with them? Aren't they looking at the scanner?
You win the bet, Captain. Looks like the deck gun won't do it. We'll have to put a torpedo into her.
Looks like the crew are getting the message. Are all their lifeboats launched?
Er, ja.
Well, wait until they're well clear, then fire one amidships.
Come on, we've got to. Are you barmy or something? Even if you could get back in your crate, that won't save you.
I assure you you've no idea, young lady.
We've got to get to the lifeboats before it
Boom! Falling metal.
I never get used to that sight.
No, sir.
Right, let's get underway. Can't risk staying on the surface. They may have transmitted a distress call. Place could be crawling with British destroyers in a matter of
Captain!
Captain, look there. Two survivors in the water, clinging to that box.
Ach, they'll never make it to their boats now. Damn them.
They're heading for us. Do we let them drown?
We rescued the dog out of the water for Lippe yesterday. We are not barbarians, Rudi. Bring them aboard.
Hatch opens. Coughing.
Thank you, Captain. We appreciate your kindness, but er
Seal the hatch.
Sir.
Clang.
Periscope depth. Helm turn forty five degrees starboard.
Yes, Captain.
Tanks blow, U-boat submerges.
Periscope depth.
(sotto) Christ, what are they going to do with us?
(sotto) I'd keep quiet if I were you.
No sign of destroyers. Keep a look-out, Leutnant Zentener.
Jawohl, Captain.
So, you speak German.
Er, that would seem to be the case.
But you speak it like an English gentleman. And what are these clothes you are wearing? You look like your King George expecting to play cricket in the Atlantic Ocean.
Laughter.
Hmm, I've always thought it was unfair to say the Germans have no sense of humour.
Your grammar is out of a text book, my friend. Why isn't an educated young man like you serving as an officer on a British warship or leading a valiant charge across the trenches?
I have flat feet, I'm afraid.
What is your name?
I'm the Doctor.
Doctor? That's a profession, not a name.
It's all I have.
Who is this? Girl! What is your name?
Eh?
She doesn't speak German, apparently.
Then you tell me, Doctor.
I don't know her name.
You cross the Atlantic in a ship with a crew of no more than twenty, and you don't know the name of what I presume was the only female aboard? That seems odd.
Yes, doesn't it?
Captain, smoke on the horizon. Something's closing fast.
Action stations!
Er, what do you intend to do with us?
Load torpedo tubes. Drop you off next time we sink one of your ships. Get these prisoners out of the control room.
Jawohl, Captain. Move. Move!
Ah yes, that's more like it. I thought there was too much civility about.
What's happening? What's going on?
(sotto) It's all right. It's all right.
Let's see. Making about twenty three knots, ja?
Ja, Captain. Must be a destroyer.
Most likely. Let's not give her a chance to ram us. Take us down to twenty metres.
Dive to twenty metres.
Twenty metres, sir.
In here.
Oh Christ, it stinks in here.
Yes, it's not very pleasant.
What was all that chat about back there? And how come you speak German?
It's a gift. It would seem the Royal Navy have come to your rescue a little late, I'm afraid.
They'll pick up the others while we're stuck down here, all 'cos of you.

I didn't fire the torpedoes. Now then, let me get my bearings. The Captain mentioned King George, the trenches, he waited until he thought the survivors had got away in the lifeboats before he sank the ship, and there was no sonar equipment in the control room. Must be the First World War.
First? What are you on about?
And what is your name, by the way?
Helen. Why?
Sorry, is that Ellen or Helen?
(aspirates) Helen. And who are you, then?
Well, Helen, I'm sorry I got you into this. I'm the Doctor. How do you do?
Oh, charmed, I'm sure. Now what were you saying to that Captain? Are you a Hun spy or something?

I assure you I'm just as anxious to get out of this submarine as you are. And if I were a spy. A spy. That's a thought. The ship broke up so the Tardis floated to the surface. I can adjust this to track the old girl, and that Time Lord was rather insistent I left this place. Hello! (thumps on door) Hello! Anyone out there? I have to speak to your Captain! It's a matter of the utmost importance to the Kaiser.
Sounds like another destroyer, circling, looking for us while the other ship picks up the survivors. They're getting clever. We daren't risk surfacing. Damn. Hirsch. Hirsch, are you there?
[OC]: Captain.
How are the batteries?
[OC]: Not good. They need to be fully recharged. We have to surface.

It's a little busy up there at the moment, Hirsch. All we can do for now is conserve power. We'll crawl away at low speed and surface in one hour, Rudi. And keep a close eye on the depth gauge. We don't want to drift up.
Yes, Captain. Three knots. Maintain twenty metres.
Captain, the male prisoner, he is demanding to speak to you.
Demanding?
He says he has vital information for the Kaiser.
(laughs) Well, I seem to have a little time on my hands. Bring him to my cabin.
So, Doctor, you have something to tell me.
Yes, Captain er, Schwieger, is it?
Yes.
Yes, something I couldn't say in company. Something concerning security and war effort.
Continue, Doctor.
As you are no doubt aware, the ship on which I was travelling was bound for Liverpool en route from New York.
I had no idea, but I take your word for it.
I am a security agent in the service of the Imperial German Army. In New York, I was able to obtain vital information concerning American involvement in the war.
The Americans are not involved in the war. At least, not directly.
Ah, not yet.
And why should I believe you? Presumably you are going to tell me that as a spy, you
carry no proof of identification.
I can give you all the proof you need.
Really. Go ahead. Amaze me.
Documents containing information on top secret American troop and naval deployments are contained in a watertight crate which was aboard that ship.
Which is now at the bottom of the Atlantic. How convenient for you, Doctor.
No, Captain. The ship broke up and my crate is fitted with buoyancy. It's up there now, floating on the surface.
And how would you suggest we go about retrieving it?
The crate is large, and its markings are very distinctive.

Doctor, the U-20 is nearing the end of a very long and dangerous tour of duty. There are two British destroyers up there as we speak, and I will not turn this boat around and risk my crew for a lot of papers, whether they exist in your precious crate or only in your mind. Schmidt!
Captain.
Take him away.
Jawohl, sir.
No, wait, you don't understand. I must
Must what, Doctor?
You're endangering the entire German war effort and putting your own career at significant risk, Captain Schwieger.
If I am jeopardising some vital mission for Turpitz or the Kaiser, I shall willingly accept punishment when we have returned to Emden.
Are you saying that you don't believe me?
Whether I believe you or not is irrelevant. I have to base my command decisions on fact, and my primary responsibility is to my crew and to my mission.
I can see that you're a brave and honourable man, Schwieger. I hope that both of us can live with the consequences of your decision.
That is a state of affairs I am well accustomed to, Doctor.
This way. Get a move on.
Thank you so much. Oh, tell me, Mister Schmidt, wasn't it? How on Earth do you put up with the appalling smells down here?
Keep your mouth shut. Argh!
What's the matter? Are you all (pause) Time distortion.
Keep your mouth shut. Move it.
But
Move it.
Get in.
Ow. Thank you.
Door shuts.
Didn't go very well with your friend the Captain, then?
I'm afraid not.
What are you doing?
Shouldn't you be on the other side of that hatch? Can we help you, Schmidt?
Grunts.
What's the matter with him?
I don't know. Time distortion again.
What?
Punch. Roar.
Wait! Stop hitting him!
I don't think the Captain ordered
Oh, stop it! Stop it, for God's sake. You'll kill him! Oh, stop it!
[OC]: The Doctor's life is forfeit. (echoes) The Doctor's life is forfeit.
Help, somebody! Quickly! Help!
My God. Schmidt! Schmidt, no! No, leave him! Zentener, help me restrain Schmidt. The man is possessed. Schmidt, for God's sake!
Final punch. Thud.
Take him, Zentener. Tie him to his bunk.
Yes, Captain.
Doctor, what happened here?
I think you're right, Captain. He was possessed.
He was trying to kill you.
Yes, that too.
But why?
The Time Lord. I heard the Time Lord. He wanted to kill me. Why? And why do they have to resort to temporal thought projection? They must have limited power resources. TTP only requires
You are not making any sense to me. I will have the medical orderly clean you up. You, Doctor, need some schnapps inside you.
I for one am glad that the Doctor is still alive in that time zone. Your plan was brutish, Vansell. Brutish and against everything we Time Lords stand for.
If we don't stop the Doctor, the Time Lords won't stand for anything any more.
Don't you think I know that? The only instruction the Doctor has is your message that he should return to his Tardis. He is trying to do that as best he can.
But the situation has changed now he is aboard the underwater vessel.
So what do you suggest?
Our power is fading by the moment. We must divert all reserves here, to the Time Chamber, to maintain the TTP link with the human.
But
Lord President, whatever your misgivings, and whatever the cost, the Doctor must be stopped.
Ah, Rudi. Come in.
Thanks. Hirsch reports the batteries are fully charged. We can dive whenever necessary.
Let's keep the air fresh as long as we can, Rudi.
Ja.
Tell your officer of the watch to keep a sharp look-out. How's Schmidt?
Still breathing. We can't seem to wake him.
We both know that kind of thing can happen. Cramped conditions, foul stench, the heat, the cold. A man can snap.
Yes, Captain. Walther?
What is it, my friend?
You seem troubled.
That Doctor troubles me. He asks the impossible of me. He knows he asks the impossible. And yet.
First they tell me to go back into the Tardis, then they try to kill me. It doesn't make sense. I have to get back to the Tardis. Ow!
Don't be such a baby.
What is that?
Er, iodine, I think. That orderly said I should dab it on. At least, I think that's what he was trying to tell me.
Very reassuring, Helen. I take it you weren't the medic aboard your ship.
A bell sounds.
Action stations?
Maybe it's someone coming to our rescue?
Periscope depth, Captain. Look-out reported smoke on the horizon due south.
I have it, Leutnant. Eight or nine kilometres away, and smoke from four funnels, I'd say. Could be a Cunarder.
Approving mutterings.
Just tell me one thing. Are you a Hun spy or not?
Er, no. No, I'm not. But, well, I've been trying to convince the Captain that I am.
Why?
To get back to the Tardis. My crate.
That's important, isn't it.
I believe that at this moment it's just about the most important thing there is.
Oh. Ach, my head. Ropes? Hey. Hey! Who tied me up? What happened? I
[OC]: (echoing) Schmidt. You must kill the Doctor.
The Doctor?
[OC]: The prisoner in the sickbay. Find a weapon, kill him. Kill him now.
Captain, Lance identifies her as the Aquitania, Lusitania or Mauritania. Whichever, that's more than thirty thousand tons.

Let me see. Ah yes. And Zentener, she's turning to starboard by about twenty to thirty degrees. The chart, man. My God, we would never have been able to match her speed, but she is coming towards us! Our courses will intersect here.
I have to find a way to convince or force Schwieger to turn back so I can find the Tardis.
You couldn't get into it before. What makes you think you'll be able to now?
I don't know, Helen. Blind faith?
Hatch undogged.
Ah, Schmidt. Feeling better?
Pistol cocked.
(sotto) Doctor, he's got a gun.
Yes, thank you, Helen. That hadn't escaped my attention.
The Doctor must die.
Now why is that, Schmidt? Just think about it. You don't even know me. Just, just think about it. I'm in the German Army. I'm on your side. Why should you want to shoot me?
I, I cannot
Well, at least you're confused.
[OC]: Running out of power, are you? Now listen to me. There's no need to get so heavy- handed. I know what you want me to do and I'm trying to do it. Do you hear me?
[OC]: Do you think they can hear you?
Vansell, you must give him a chance. He's trying
Good intentions won't save us, Lord President. Will you order me not to send the command again?
No.
Schmidt. Now listen to me. Kill him.
Schmidt groans.
Oh, dear.
No!
Gunshot.
What the hell was that?
The prisoners!
Stay here, Rudi. Hauppe, Lippe, with me.
Helen cocks the gun.
Stay back, Schmidt, or whatever your damn Hun name is. Doctor? Doctor, you all right? I've got his gun. Doctor?
Still, still alive, thank you.
Schmidt groans. Gunshot. Thud.
Oh, is he dead? Did I kill him?
A hole that big in a person usually indicates zero chance of survival. You didn't have to do that, you know.
What about you?
He made a mess of my shoulder. All in all, you saved my life, Helen. Now, give me the gun.
But
Give it to me. Thank you.
Put the gun down, Doctor. My men are armed.
Stay where you are. If you want your Captain to live, put your weapons down. Now!
Weapons on metal deck.
Good. Ow.
What are you hoping to achieve, Doctor?
We're going to the control room, Captain. You're going to turn this submarine around.
But
You reverse our course.
Or you shoot me?
What do you think?
Your eyes betray you, Doctor.
What's he saying, Doctor? What's he saying?
I don't know who you really are, or why you need your precious crate so badly, but you are not ready to kill.
Here, give me that gun. I'll do it. Tell him, Doctor. I'll do it. Do you understand me, you ruddy Huns? You put an 'ole in my ship. I'll put an ole in the lot of you if I have to.
Well, Schwieger?
Whatever she's saying, I think she means it.
Beeping.
What is that device?
Oh, the latest thing, Captain. I would say we're pretty much back where we started, give or take a few nautical miles.
You're more resilient than I thought, Doctor. I expected you to have bled to death by now.
Hmm. Periscope depth, Leutnant Zentener.
Howling winds, crashing waves.
Up periscope. Ah yes. I can see her.
The Tardis?
Yes. Surface, please.
The Tardis. What is that, a ship?
Gunshot.
Stay back,
Helen.
What's he saying, Doctor?
Just don't. Surface, Captain.
Do as he says.
Hatch opens, footsteps.
There she is. The Tardis.
What are you going to do now, Doctor?
Tell him to shurrup, Doctor. Tell him I'll shoot if I have to.
I think he knows that.
Where are you going?
Believe me, I'm sorry, but I have no choice. This is where we part company, Helen.
What? You just can't (punch) oh!
I think the game's up, Doctor. We have the girl. Climb back down or I shoot.
Are you ready to kill, Captain? Look after the girl, won't you? She didn't really understand, you see. Auf Wiedersehen!
Splash!
Captain, what happened?
Suicidal fool.
Explosion.
British destroyer about five hundred metres to port. Captain, we must dive!
Where's the girl?
What? She was. But.
Never mind. Action stations. Crash dive!
Oh, well done, old girl. Still afloat, en? The key.
Rattles lock.
Oh no, I don't believe it. Still won't open. (thumps on door) Turlough! Tegan! Open the door! Open the door!
A shell explodes nearby.
The Time Lords really do want me dead.

ZENTENER: Periscope depth, Captain.

ZENTENER: I could do with the fresh air myself, Captain.
SCHWIEGER: And miss the foul stench down here? I thought you loved your country, Rudi. Looks as if the weather is favourable for a change. Ah!
ZENTENER: What is it?
SCHWIEGER: A merchantman.
ZENTENER: Move to torpedo range?
SCHWIEGER: No. Take a look for yourself. What tonnage would you estimate, Rudi?
ZENTENER: Five, maybe six thousand?
SCHWIEGER: Mmm, I concur. Maybe not worth wasting the torpedo. We go in for a closer look, ja?
ZENTENER: Ja.
SCHWIEGER: Helm, thirty degrees starboard. Full ahead.
HELM: Thirty degrees starboard. Full ahead.
ZENTENER: She's flying the British flag.
SCHWIEGER: Which means her Captain is either very bold or very stupid.
SCHWIEGER: (A ship's bell rings eight bells as the Tardis materialises. The door opens and the Fifth Doctor steps out into the SS Centurion.)

DOCTOR: Hello. This looks promising. Or not, as the case may be.
DOCTOR: Definitely coming from this direction. Ah. I thought so. A tear in the fabric of Time.
VANSELL: [OC]: Doctor, Doctor, Doctor, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Who is that?

HELEN: (a Liver bird) Who are you talking to?
DOCTOR: Ah, hello. Where did you spring from?
HELEN: And just who the hell are you, for that matter.
DOCTOR: Well, er, Turlough! Tegan!
HELEN: I think perhaps you should come and see the Captain.
DOCTOR: I don't think we need to bother

DOCTOR: Has he indeed? Look, you couldn't just forget you'd seen me?
HELEN: (laughs) You're a cheeky one and no mistake.
HELEN: Must be a ruddy Hun U-boat!
DOCTOR: Turlough! Tegan! What's the matter with them? Aren't they looking at the scanner?
ZENTENER: You win the bet, Captain. Looks like the deck gun won't do it. We'll have to put a torpedo into her.
SCHWIEGER: Looks like the crew are getting the message. Are all their lifeboats launched?
ZENTENER: Er, ja.
SCHWIEGER: Well, wait until they're well clear, then fire one amidships.
HELEN: Come on, we've got to. Are you barmy or something? Even if you could get back in your crate, that won't save you.
DOCTOR: I assure you you've no idea, young lady.
HELEN: We've got to get to the lifeboats before it
SCHWIEGER: I never get used to that sight.
ZENTENER: No, sir.
SCHWIEGER: Right, let's get underway. Can't risk staying on the surface. They may have transmitted a distress call. Place could be crawling with British destroyers in a matter of
MAN: Captain!
ZENTENER: Captain, look there. Two survivors in the water, clinging to that box.
SCHWIEGER: Ach, they'll never make it to their boats now. Damn them.
ZENTENER: They're heading for us. Do we let them drown?
SCHWIEGER: We rescued the dog out of the water for Lippe yesterday. We are not barbarians, Rudi. Bring them aboard.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Captain. We appreciate your kindness, but er
SCHWIEGER: Seal the hatch.
MAN: Sir.
SCHWIEGER: Periscope depth. Helm turn forty five degrees starboard.
HELM: Yes, Captain.
ZENTENER: Periscope depth.
HELEN: (sotto) Christ, what are they going to do with us?
DOCTOR: (sotto) I'd keep quiet if I were you.
SCHWIEGER: No sign of destroyers. Keep a look-out, Leutnant Zentener.
ZENTENER: Jawohl, Captain.
SCHWIEGER: So, you speak German.

SCHWIEGER: But you speak it like an English gentleman. And what are these clothes you are wearing? You look like your King George expecting to play cricket in the Atlantic Ocean.
DOCTOR: Hmm, I've always thought it was unfair to say the Germans have no sense of humour.
SCHWIEGER: Your grammar is out of a text book, my friend. Why isn't an educated young man like you serving as an officer on a British warship or leading a valiant charge across the trenches?

ZENTENER: Captain, smoke on the horizon. Something's closing fast.

SCHMIDT: Jawohl, Captain. Move. Move!
DOCTOR: Ah yes, that's more like it. I thought there was too much civility about.
HELEN: What's happening? What's going on?
DOCTOR: (sotto) It's all right. It's all right.
SCHWIEGER: Let's see. Making about twenty three knots, ja?
ZENTENER: Ja, Captain. Must be a destroyer.
SCHWIEGER: Most likely. Let's not give her a chance to ram us. Take us down to twenty metres.

MAN: Twenty metres, sir.
SCHMIDT: In here.
HELEN: Oh Christ, it stinks in here.
DOCTOR: Yes, it's not very pleasant.
HELEN: What was all that chat about back there? And how come you speak German?

DOCTOR: I didn't fire the torpedoes. Now then, let me get my bearings. The Captain mentioned King George, the trenches, he waited until he thought the survivors had got away in the lifeboats before he sank the ship, and there was no sonar equipment in the control room. Must be the First World War.
HELEN: First? What are you on about?
DOCTOR: And what is your name, by the way?
HELEN: Helen. Why?

DOCTOR: Well, Helen, I'm sorry I got you into this. I'm the Doctor. How do you do?
HELEN: Oh, charmed, I'm sure. Now what were you saying to that Captain? Are you a Hun spy or something?
DOCTOR: I assure you I'm just as anxious to get out of this submarine as you are. And if I were a spy. A spy. That's a thought. The ship broke up so the Tardis floated to the surface. I can adjust this to track the old girl, and that Time Lord was rather insistent I left this place. Hello! (thumps on door) Hello! Anyone out there? I have to speak to your Captain! It's a matter of the utmost importance to the Kaiser.
SCHWIEGER: Sounds like another destroyer, circling, looking for us while the other ship picks up the survivors. They're getting clever. We daren't risk surfacing. Damn. Hirsch. Hirsch, are you there?
HIRSCH: [OC]: Captain.
SCHWIEGER: How are the batteries?
HIRSCH: [OC]: Not good. They need to be fully recharged. We have to surface.
SCHWIEGER: It's a little busy up there at the moment, Hirsch. All we can do for now is conserve power. We'll crawl away at low speed and surface in one hour, Rudi. And keep a close eye on the depth gauge. We don't want to drift up.
ZENTENER: Yes, Captain. Three knots. Maintain twenty metres.
SCHMIDT: Captain, the male prisoner, he is demanding to speak to you.
SCHWIEGER: Demanding?
SCHMIDT: He says he has vital information for the Kaiser.
SCHWIEGER: (laughs) Well, I seem to have a little time on my hands. Bring him to my cabin.
SCHWIEGER: So, Doctor, you have something to tell me.
DOCTOR: Yes, Captain er, Schwieger, is it?
SCHWIEGER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Yes, something I couldn't say in company. Something concerning security and war effort.
SCHWIEGER: Continue, Doctor.
DOCTOR: As you are no doubt aware, the ship on which I was travelling was bound for Liverpool en route from New York.
SCHWIEGER: I had no idea, but I take your word for it.
DOCTOR: I am a security agent in the service of the Imperial German Army. In New York, I was able to obtain vital information concerning American involvement in the war.
SCHWIEGER: The Americans are not involved in the war. At least, not directly.
DOCTOR: Ah, not yet.
SCHWIEGER: And why should I believe you? Presumably you are going to tell me that as a spy, you
SCHWIEGER: carry no proof of identification.
DOCTOR: I can give you all the proof you need.
SCHWIEGER: Really. Go ahead. Amaze me.
DOCTOR: Documents containing information on top secret American troop and naval deployments are contained in a watertight crate which was aboard that ship.
SCHWIEGER: Which is now at the bottom of the Atlantic. How convenient for you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: No, Captain. The ship broke up and my crate is fitted with buoyancy. It's up there now, floating on the surface.
SCHWIEGER: And how would you suggest we go about retrieving it?
DOCTOR: The crate is large, and its markings are very distinctive.
SCHWIEGER: Doctor, the U-20 is nearing the end of a very long and dangerous tour of duty. There are two British destroyers up there as we speak, and I will not turn this boat around and risk my crew for a lot of papers, whether they exist in your precious crate or only in your mind. Schmidt!
SCHMIDT: Captain.
SCHWIEGER: Take him away.
SCHMIDT: Jawohl, sir.
DOCTOR: No, wait, you don't understand. I must

DOCTOR: You're endangering the entire German war effort and putting your own career at significant risk, Captain Schwieger.
SCHWIEGER: If I am jeopardising some vital mission for Turpitz or the Kaiser, I shall willingly accept punishment when we have returned to Emden.

SCHWIEGER: Whether I believe you or not is irrelevant. I have to base my command decisions on fact, and my primary responsibility is to my crew and to my mission.
DOCTOR: I can see that you're a brave and honourable man, Schwieger. I hope that both of us can live with the consequences of your decision.
SCHWIEGER: That is a state of affairs I am well accustomed to, Doctor.
SCHMIDT: This way. Get a move on.
DOCTOR: Thank you so much. Oh, tell me, Mister Schmidt, wasn't it? How on Earth do you put up with the appalling smells down here?
SCHMIDT: Keep your mouth shut. Argh!
DOCTOR: What's the matter? Are you all (pause) Time distortion.
SCHMIDT: Keep your mouth shut. Move it.
DOCTOR: But
SCHMIDT: Move it.
SCHMIDT: Get in.
DOCTOR: Ow. Thank you.
HELEN: Didn't go very well with your friend the Captain, then?
DOCTOR: I'm afraid not.
HELEN: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: Shouldn't you be on the other side of that hatch? Can we help you, Schmidt?
HELEN: What's the matter with him?
DOCTOR: I don't know. Time distortion again.
HELEN: What?
HELEN: Wait! Stop hitting him!
DOCTOR: I don't think the Captain ordered

VANSELL: [OC]: The Doctor's life is forfeit. (echoes) The Doctor's life is forfeit.
HELEN: Help, somebody! Quickly! Help!
SCHWIEGER: My God. Schmidt! Schmidt, no! No, leave him! Zentener, help me restrain Schmidt. The man is possessed. Schmidt, for God's sake!
SCHWIEGER: Take him, Zentener. Tie him to his bunk.
ZENTENER: Yes, Captain.
SCHWIEGER: Doctor, what happened here?
DOCTOR: I think you're right, Captain. He was possessed.

DOCTOR: The Time Lord. I heard the Time Lord. He wanted to kill me. Why? And why do they have to resort to temporal thought projection? They must have limited power resources. TTP only requires

PRESIDENT: I for one am glad that the Doctor is still alive in that time zone. Your plan was brutish, Vansell. Brutish and against everything we Time Lords stand for.

PRESIDENT: Don't you think I know that? The only instruction the Doctor has is your message that he should return to his Tardis. He is trying to do that as best he can.

VANSELL: Lord President, whatever your misgivings, and whatever the cost, the Doctor must be stopped.
SCHWIEGER: Ah, Rudi. Come in.
ZENTENER: Thanks. Hirsch reports the batteries are fully charged. We can dive whenever necessary.
SCHWIEGER: Let's keep the air fresh as long as we can, Rudi.
ZENTENER: Ja.
SCHWIEGER: Tell your officer of the watch to keep a sharp look-out. How's Schmidt?
ZENTENER: Still breathing. We can't seem to wake him.
SCHWIEGER: We both know that kind of thing can happen. Cramped conditions, foul stench, the heat, the cold. A man can snap.
ZENTENER: Yes, Captain. Walther?
SCHWIEGER: What is it, my friend?
ZENTENER: You seem troubled.
SCHWIEGER: That Doctor troubles me. He asks the impossible of me. He knows he asks the impossible. And yet.

HELEN: Don't be such a baby.
DOCTOR: What is that?
HELEN: Er, iodine, I think. That orderly said I should dab it on. At least, I think that's what he was trying to tell me.
DOCTOR: Very reassuring, Helen. I take it you weren't the medic aboard your ship.
DOCTOR: Action stations?
HELEN: Maybe it's someone coming to our rescue?
ZENTENER: Periscope depth, Captain. Look-out reported smoke on the horizon due south.
SCHWIEGER: I have it, Leutnant. Eight or nine kilometres away, and smoke from four funnels, I'd say. Could be a Cunarder.
HELEN: Just tell me one thing. Are you a Hun spy or not?
DOCTOR: Er, no. No, I'm not. But, well, I've been trying to convince the Captain that I am.
HELEN: Why?
DOCTOR: To get back to the Tardis. My crate.
HELEN: That's important, isn't it.
DOCTOR: I believe that at this moment it's just about the most important thing there is.
SCHMIDT: Oh. Ach, my head. Ropes? Hey. Hey! Who tied me up? What happened? I

SCHMIDT: The Doctor?
VANSELL: [OC]: The prisoner in the sickbay. Find a weapon, kill him. Kill him now.

SCHWIEGER: Let me see. Ah yes. And Zentener, she's turning to starboard by about twenty to thirty degrees. The chart, man. My God, we would never have been able to match her speed, but she is coming towards us! Our courses will intersect here.
DOCTOR: I have to find a way to convince or force Schwieger to turn back so I can find the Tardis.
HELEN: You couldn't get into it before. What makes you think you'll be able to now?
DOCTOR: I don't know, Helen. Blind faith?
DOCTOR: Ah, Schmidt. Feeling better?

DOCTOR: Yes, thank you, Helen. That hadn't escaped my attention.
SCHMIDT: The Doctor must die.
DOCTOR: Now why is that, Schmidt? Just think about it. You don't even know me. Just, just think about it. I'm in the German Army. I'm on your side. Why should you want to shoot me?
SCHMIDT: I, I cannot
DOCTOR: Well, at least you're confused.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Running out of power, are you? Now listen to me. There's no need to get so heavy- handed. I know what you want me to do and I'm trying to do it. Do you hear me?
HELEN: [OC]: Do you think they can hear you?
PRESIDENT: Vansell, you must give him a chance. He's trying
VANSELL: Good intentions won't save us, Lord President. Will you order me not to send the command again?
PRESIDENT: No.
VANSELL: Schmidt. Now listen to me. Kill him.
DOCTOR: Oh, dear.
HELEN: No!
SCHWIEGER: What the hell was that?
ZENTENER: The prisoners!
SCHWIEGER: Stay here, Rudi. Hauppe, Lippe, with me.
HELEN: Stay back, Schmidt, or whatever your damn Hun name is. Doctor? Doctor, you all right? I've got his gun. Doctor?
DOCTOR: Still, still alive, thank you.
HELEN: Oh, is he dead? Did I kill him?
DOCTOR: A hole that big in a person usually indicates zero chance of survival. You didn't have to do that, you know.
HELEN: What about you?
DOCTOR: He made a mess of my shoulder. All in all, you saved my life, Helen. Now, give me the gun.
HELEN: But
DOCTOR: Give it to me. Thank you.
SCHWIEGER: Put the gun down, Doctor. My men are armed.
DOCTOR: Stay where you are. If you want your Captain to live, put your weapons down. Now!
DOCTOR: Good. Ow.
SCHWIEGER: What are you hoping to achieve, Doctor?
DOCTOR: We're going to the control room, Captain. You're going to turn this submarine around.
SCHWIEGER: But

SCHWIEGER: Or you shoot me?
DOCTOR: What do you think?
SCHWIEGER: Your eyes betray you, Doctor.
HELEN: What's he saying, Doctor? What's he saying?
SCHWIEGER: I don't know who you really are, or why you need your precious crate so badly, but you are not ready to kill.
HELEN: Here, give me that gun. I'll do it. Tell him, Doctor. I'll do it. Do you understand me, you ruddy Huns? You put an 'ole in my ship. I'll put an ole in the lot of you if I have to.

SCHWIEGER: Whatever she's saying, I think she means it.
SCHWIEGER: What is that device?
DOCTOR: Oh, the latest thing, Captain. I would say we're pretty much back where we started, give or take a few nautical miles.
SCHWIEGER: You're more resilient than I thought, Doctor. I expected you to have bled to death by now.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Periscope depth, Leutnant Zentener.
DOCTOR: Up periscope. Ah yes. I can see her.
HELEN: The Tardis?
DOCTOR: Yes. Surface, please.
SCHWIEGER: The Tardis. What is that, a ship?
HELEN: Stay back,
DOCTOR: Helen.
HELEN: What's he saying, Doctor?

SCHWIEGER: Do as he says.
DOCTOR: There she is. The Tardis.
SCHWIEGER: What are you going to do now, Doctor?

HELEN: What? You just can't (punch) oh!
SCHWIEGER: I think the game's up, Doctor. We have the girl. Climb back down or I shoot.
DOCTOR: Are you ready to kill, Captain? Look after the girl, won't you? She didn't really understand, you see. Auf Wiedersehen!
ZENTENER: Captain, what happened?
SCHWIEGER: Suicidal fool.
ZENTENER: British destroyer about five hundred metres to port. Captain, we must dive!
SCHWIEGER: Where's the girl?
ZENTENER: What? She was. But.
SCHWIEGER: Never mind. Action stations. Crash dive!
DOCTOR: Oh, well done, old girl. Still afloat, en? The key.
DOCTOR: Oh no, I don't believe it. Still won't open. (thumps on door) Turlough! Tegan! Open the door! Open the door!
DOCTOR: The Time Lords really do want me dead.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Yes. Yes, that's it. What? Traces of some other kind of being inhabiting the Vortex at each nexus point. Apparently female.
Door opens.
Ah, Lord President.
Vansell, a Castellan informs me

Lord President, I have traced the Doctor again, this time in his sixth incarnation. There was an incident in the Kurgon system. Somehow it concerns the legendary Time beast, the Temperon. I must have all available power resources transferred
Vansell! The transduction barrier has been breached. Alien timeships are materialising everywhere. We have no power left. They, they are demanding our unconditional surrender.
But who, who are they?
They're calling themselves the Knights of Velyshaa, and it appears there's nothing we can do to stop them.
Then the Doctor is beyond our reach now.
Temporal particle acceleration now reaching optimum reading. Prepare to engage vortex drive. Proximity alarm! Increase power to restraint field immediately!
[OC]: You must not succeed.
Boom! Then the sound of a Tardis's time engines.
It's no good. It's no good. I can't stop it. The Tardis is being dragged in!
Silence.
No Tardis. Now, now what happened? There was some kind of ship, then an explosion, and (door opens, footsteps) What?
Oh, er, I didn't see you there.
Evidently.
I didn't expect to find anyone still here. Can I help you, sir?
Help me? What did you have in mind?
Well, a drink. Something to eat.
Oh, no. No, thank you. That's very kind of you but
(laughs) Just doing my job, sir.
Your job?
Yes. I'm a waitress.
(pause) Yes. Yes, of course you are. Thank you. Well, hadn't you better just run along?
Right. Er
Something the matter?
You are one of the delegates, aren't you?
Yes, I am one of the delegates, as a matter of fact.
Well, you know they've started, don't you?
Have they? Oh, I see. Well, better go and join them, hadn't I?
Yeah.
I seem to have forgotten the way again. Is it er this door?
No. I'll show you if you like.
Oh, thank you. Yes, you show me. Er
Yes, sir?
Oh, it's nothing. It's just that I have the strangest feeling we've met before.
Well, I've been serving drinks here in the hospitality suite since we took off from Kurgon. You've probably seen me round the place.
Yes, I expect that'll be it. Well, after you.
Oh, of course, sir. Please follow me.
[OC]: Engine room to Flight Deck.
Pilot Azimendah responding. Report status, Engine room.
[OC]: All power stacks now back to optimum levels. We're ready for you now.
Any idea what caused the fluctuation?
[OC]: I think it may have been a glitch in the secondary couplings

I love it when you talk technical. Flight Deck out. This is Star Cruiser Edifice to Kurgon Central Tracking. We are now ready to go in for closer orbit of gaseous anomaly at coordinates 83692 by 020576 mark 74. Are we clear?
[OC]: About time too, Edifice. Of course you're clear. No one else ever goes in that close. The field is yours. Good luck.
Acknowledged. We have clearance, Captain.
This is it, Azimendah. Take us in.
Don't you want to review the coordinates, sir?
Azimendah, you're an android pilot with a spotless record. I'd trust you to fly me stark naked through a cheese grater. It's your show.
Thank you, sir. Engaging main drive.

May I take this opportunity on behalf of the Kurgon government of welcoming every single delegate of the Galactic Wonders Commission to the pride of our fleet, the Star Cruiser Edifice. As you can see on the main screen, we are now moving into a close orbit of what we hope your Commission will classify as the Kurgon Wonder (continues under)
(sotto) Do you know your way to your seat?
(sotto) I'm afraid I've forgotten that as well.
(sotto) Oh. Well, look, there are a few empty places round to the right of the auditorium. Just take your pick, then log on.
(sotto) Right. Thank you. Oh, you're not staying?
(sotto) No, I've duties to attend to.
(sotto) Of course. Thank you. Excuse me. Sorry. Excuse me. Yes. Excuse me. Thank you. Ah. Now, computer terminal.
You are now logged in. Do you wish to discover more?
Yes please.
Welcome, delegate. The Star Cruiser Edifice is now in orbit around the Kurgon system's famous gaseous anomaly.
Hmm.
You will observe the beautiful colours and the absolute stillness of the incandescent light.
Mmm, beautiful. And somewhat familiar.

The anomaly measures two hundred and fifty million cubic metrons, and the intensity of light has remained at a constant seven hundred and fifty thousand lumens since analysis of the anomaly commenced two hundred years ago.
Would you please keep the noise down, old chap?
Hmm? Oh, sorry. Have I missed much?
Correcting seven degrees left on horizontal thrusters. Decreasing velocity.
Alarm sounds.
Defence alarm? What the hell's going on? Pilot?
I'm not reading anything. Wait a minute. Detectors are showing a large, some kind of gigantic particle disruption field heading straight for us.
Evasive course, Azimendah. Get us out of the way!
Impossible, Captain. It's thirty million metrons in diameter.
What? Time to impact?
Boom! Both cry out.
Er, delegates, I assure you there is no cause for alarm. Just as soon as we're notified
Boom, crash, screams.
What in the name of? What is that?
At a guess, I'd say it was an enormous shard of time distortion, and it's coming this way. (distorted) Yes, time distortion, definitely time distortion.
Help me. Help me.
What? Who is that?
: I'm sorry, Captain. The particle disruption caused my internal systems to go offline momentarily. I. Oh, my God.
Clatter, coughing.
Yes, that was time distortion all right.
Oh, what's happened? Oh my God, it's horrible.
I take it you're not referring to my dress sense.
Everyone's oh, they're all. Something's killed them, but well, they look like they've been
Aged to death.
Well, yes.
Cellular time disruption. That thing must have been some kind of temporal shockwave. Yes, temporal shockwave. That would explain why the Tardis
The Tardis?
Yes, the shockwave subjected anything in its path to
Then why are we all right?
Hmm? Oh, good question, er, what's your name?
Ellie. I'm the waitress.
Yes, I remember who you are. Good question, Ellie. Good question indeed. I'm known as the Doctor, by the way. Pleased to meet you. I'm sorry it couldn't have been under more pleasant circumstances.
Yes, me too. Oh, I don't like the sound of that.
Neither do I. We'd better go and find out what it is, don't you think?
