DOCTOR: Oh, no, no, no, no, no, not at all. Let me guess. You're interested in time distortion because you've developed a little problem since the accident, haven't you?
AZIMENDAH: What makes you think that?
DOCTOR: Because when it comes down to it, I'm a bit of a know it all, really. Androids, Cybermen, Daleks, Sontarans, Ice Warriors, you name it, I can quote you chapter and verse. Need I go on?
ELLIE: I've a feeling you're going to.
DOCTOR: So in short, Azimendah, my friend, I imagine your internal chronometer has gone fuzzy. Am I right?
AZIMENDAH: I er
ELLIE: Well, I've never seen an embarrassed android before.
DOCTOR: And you can be quiet, young lady. I haven't started on you yet.
AZIMENDAH: I know longer have any way of perceiving the linear passage of time.
DOCTOR: Well, look on the bright side. Some would say that's a liberating experience.
ELLIE: Oh, now what?
DOCTOR: More time distortion?
AZIMENDAH: Sounds like it's breaking through the hull.
DOCTOR: Of course! That first encounter would have reduced the molecular elasticity of the hull. More exposure to time distortion is taking it well beyond its sell-by date.
AZIMENDAH: Hull breach!
ELLIE: We're going to get blown out into space!
DOCTOR: We've got to get out of this section and seal it off somehow.
AZIMENDAH: This way. Now! Come on!
AZIMENDAH: Right, this is it!
ELLIE: What is it?
AZIMENDAH: Damn.
ELLIE: Damn what? What are you doing? Shouldn't we be running?
AZIMENDAH: : If we don't seal off that section before the hull breaks open, there'll be no point running anywhere.
DOCTOR: Don't tell me, your emergency bulkhead door controls have turned to dust.
AZIMENDAH: Well, yes.
DOCTOR: Do you know what to do?
ELLIE: Don't tell me you do.
DOCTOR: Bulkhead construction based on the old Hadene Lestrade design. Good old Lestrade. Genius. Died penniless, you know.
AZIMENDAH: Doctor, or whoever you are, if you know how to close this bulkhead, I suggest
DOCTOR: Are you a good shot, Azimendah?
AZIMENDAH: What?
DOCTOR: A good. Oh, of course you are. Look, you see those cross-braced fusion welds either side of the archway?
AZIMENDAH: Yes. You want me to fire at them?
DOCTOR: Yes. You'll weaken the support couplings. The doors should come crashing down. Mind your feet, everyone. Well, fire, man! Fire before it's too late.
ELLIE: Nothing's happening.
AZIMENDAH: Now what?
DOCTOR: That's what. Patience is a virtue.
ELLIE: That's taken care of your hull breach, but what about the time distortion?
DOCTOR: Indeed. Azimendah, what was your course before the initial wave hit?
AZIMENDAH: We were moving into a closer orbit. I see what you're getting at.
ELLIE: You mean, we're still heading that way?
DOCTOR: The engine's cut out, but the momentum is still taking us towards your Kurgon Wonder. The closer we get, the more time distortion we're likely to encounter. Eventually I imagine we'll be completely enveloped by it. Is there any way we can get power to your directional thrusters, send us in the opposite direction?
AZIMENDAH: This is it. The engine room. Those are the reserve chemical fuel tanks.
DOCTOR: Ah, I see. Sounds healthy.
ELLIE: There's an indicator here. It reads full.
AZIMENDAH: Do you think the stuff will still be usable?
DOCTOR: It's worth a try. Can you reroute the surviving computer systems to ignite the fuel?
AZIMENDAH: As you say, it's worth a try.
ELLIE: Then we need to get to the flight deck. If those things'll let us.
PRESIDENT: Vansell, the Chancellery guard are outmatched and outnumbered by these Knights of Velyshaa. This slaughter is senseless. We have to surrender to preserve
VANSELL: No! We have to fight on. I think I've found a way to speak to the Doctor again. The timeline he's trapped in is becoming inundated with time distortion. I can use that as a carrier for a temporal signal.
PRESIDENT: There isn't enough power.
VANSELL: There is an artificial lifeform with the Doctor. Its positronic brain can be more easily influenced.
DOCTOR: Ellie, where's Azimendah?
ELLIE: Repairing the computer link to the engine room, he said. He's given me a gun in case those creatures come knocking.
DOCTOR: Er, just be careful where you're pointing it.
COMPUTER: S-s-s-s-s-cell cell analysis. Analysis complete.
DOCTOR: Ah, yes.
ELLIE: Have you identified what those things are?
DOCTOR: They're mutated viruses and bacteria.
ELLIE: They were huge!
DOCTOR: And angry. Bizarre, but the time distortion triggered some sort of accelerated evolutionary process in some of the more resistant microscopic organisms aboard. They reproduce at a fantastic rate.
ELLIE: Which means there won't be much room for us. Oh, no.
DOCTOR: What?
ELLIE: Oh, look at the main viewport.
DOCTOR: More shards of time distortion.
ELLIE: It looks like space is folding in on itself.
DOCTOR: I fear the distortion's increasing the closer we get.
ELLIE: Will it kill us?
DOCTOR: Ultimately, I imagine. I have a certain tolerance to that sort of thing, but Azimendah's circuitry, although more durable than organic tissue, is bound to have a limited lifespan. And as for you, Ellie, well, your survival is a bit of a mystery to me.
ELLIE: Don't look at me for an explanation. I'm just happy to be alive.
DOCTOR: Well, that time distortion's still some way off, so, are you going to tell me what was on that disc?
ELLIE: What? Oh. Mmm.
DOCTOR: The one whose existence you were so keen to deny?
VANSELL: Lord President! Are you
PRESIDENT: in pain) Their weaponry somehow inhibiting regeneration. I, I. Have you sent the signal to the Doctor?
VANSELL: I'm about to.
PRESIDENT: Do it! Do it before
KNIGHT: Your President is dead, Time Lord. We claim this world as part of the glorious Second Empire of the Knights of Velyshaa.
VANSELL: Not if I can help it.
KNIGHT: Destroy him!
VANSELL: Doctor. Doctor, it is done. You are our last hope, Doctor. Do not free the Temperon.
DOCTOR: You mean you're part of some underground anti-government movement?
ELLIE: The movement was founded by the telepaths in our race many years ago, when they began to hear cries of pain emanating from the Wonder.
DOCTOR: I've heard them myself. A cry for help. And what do your people think the Wonder really is?
ELLIE: A terrible catastrophe frozen in time.
DOCTOR: Yes. I witnessed that catastrophe, and my ship became part of it.
ELLIE: This disc is a copy of the audio transmission, deciphered from a relic held for generations by one of our religious orders. We ran it through a translator, and
DOCTOR: It must have been part of the debris in the initial explosion. Perhaps some kind of flight recorder?
ELLIE: I'm sorry, Doctor. I should have trusted you before, but, well, you could have been a government agent. They'll stop at nothing to prevent us from telling the truth about the Kurgon Wonder. I was going to play the disc into the main computer so that the delegates could hear the truth for themselves.
AZIMENDAH: I think the cables will hold. We should have enough fuel to. What are you doing?
DOCTOR: I think this is something you should listen to, Azimendah. Go on, Ellie. Put it into the computer.
ELLIE: The translator worked on most of it.
VOICE: [OC]: Temperon particle acceleration now reaching optimum reading. Prepare to engage vortex drive. Proximity alarm! Increase power to restraint field immediately.
TEMPERON: [OC]: You must not succeed.
DOCTOR: That was the sound of my ship, the Tardis. Temperon particles. Temperon? Yes, of course. The only way you're going to find Temperon particles is in the Temperon!
ELLIE: The what?
DOCTOR: The legend of the Temperon. Have you never heard of it?
ELLIE: Well, no.
AZIMENDAH: So the waitress turns out to be one of those superstitious weirdos.
DOCTOR: The Temperon. The legendary time beast folds its way through the oceans of Time, serene, sublime. And it sounded as if it was caught in some ghastly experiment, which it then attempted to destroy. But because of the massive release of Temperon particles, its moment of death was somehow frozen.
AZIMENDAH: (laughs) I have never heard such a lot of
DOCTOR: Maybe so, but didn't you hear the disc?
AZIMENDAH: Yes, but
ELLIE: So this creature is trapped, in agony. Oh, we've got to set it free.
DOCTOR: I know. For one thing, it's the only way I'm going to get the Tardis back. But how? I must think.
ELLIE: Doctor, look out!
DOCTOR: This is it. If we don't reverse the engines now, we'll never
VANSELL: [OC]: Doctor. Doctor.
DOCTOR: What? Azimendah, what's happening to you?
ELLIE: He, he's going mad! It's the time distortion. It's fried his circuits. Stand back, Doctor.
DOCTOR: No, Ellie. What are you doing? Put that gun down!
VANSELL: [OC]: Doctor, the High Council of the Time Lords.
DOCTOR: The Time Lords?
VANSELL: [OC]: The High Council of the Time Lords commands you to
AZIMENDAH: Argh!
DOCTOR: Ellie! What did you do that for?
ELLIE: Couldn't you see? He was going to kill us. He was raising his gun.
DOCTOR: No, he wasn't. You. I do recognise you. I don't know how or why, but every time I look at you, every time I hear your voice, there's something. Something.
ELLIE: Too late, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Who are you?
DOCTOR: (wakes) Back in the Tardis. Why? Oh, surrounded by Temperon particles. I'm at the centre of the Kurgon Wonder. The Temperon must have sucked me back into the explosion. To set it free! That's it. Temperon particles adhering to the old girl's outer shell. If I dematerialise, I should take the Temperon with me. Well, it's worth a try, anyway.
DOCTOR: Come on. Come on. It's working. It's working!
DOCTOR: Oh no. Temperon particles are breaching the outer shell, invading the interior dimensions of the Tardis.
TEMPERON: Doctor. Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, that's me.
TEMPERON: You set me free.
DOCTOR: Oh, it was nothing. I'm sure you'd have done the same for me. Look, could I just point out you're actually damaging the Tardis's
TEMPERON: Now the Knights of Velyshaa are free to carry out their experiment.
DOCTOR: Knights of. What are you talking about?
TEMPERON: The Knights of Velyshaa. You have set them free.
DOCTOR: No! (echoes) No, what are you doing? Please, stay back. You're smothering me. I can't breathe.
TEMPERON: Beware the Sirens of Time.

elements.text: [Part Four]
6: Can't breathe. I can't breathe. (deep breath in and out) I've been completely absorbed by you, haven't I?
Yes, Doctor. Beware the Sirens of Time.
6: Beware? What do you mean?
Beware the Sirens of Time. Urgh.
6: Temperon? What is it? What's happening to you? Temperon? Temperon!
7: Folds its way through the oceans of Time, serene, sublime.
6: Who? Oh. Oh, so that's how things turned out for me.
5: And for me, it seems. Any more of us?
7: Just the three, it would appear.
6: Well, we must be thankful for small mercies, mustn't we?
5: We're on Gallifrey. This is the Panopticon.
6: Decorators have made a bit of a mess.
7: Looks like it's been neglected for a long time. Years, perhaps. Death and decay.
6: Death? What do you mean?
7: Don't you feel it?
5: Yes, an emptiness. Almost like remembering a bad dream.
6: Telepathic impulses. Most likely from the Time Lords. But where are they? And what happened here?
5: Probably something pretty catastrophic, or the three of us wouldn't be here together at the same time.
7: Yes, there are laws about this sort of thing, after all.
6: Laws that the Temperon saw fit to break. I take it you two were brought here by the Temperon?
5: Yes.
7: Mmm. Not a very comfortable way to travel.
6: But it certainly seemed less volatile than its close cousins, the Chronavores.
5: Beware the Sirens of Time.
7: The Sirens of Time.
6: Never heard of them.
5: Quite. Perhaps it's time we shared our experiences, agreed?
6+7: Agreed.
6: Contact?
5: Contact.
7: Contact. [memory] I think I should change the coordinates.
[memory]: Doctor. Doctor. Doctor.
7 [memory]: Time Lords? Your name! Tell me your name!
[memory]: Elenya.
[memory]: Sancroff, First Knight of Velyshaa, I will strike you down in the name of all that is good in the universe.
[memory]: You're some kind of
[memory]: War criminal. A long time ago, my dear. A lifetime ago.
5 [memory]: A tear in the fabric of Time.
[memory]: Doctor. Doctor.
5 [memory]: Ah, hello. Where did you spring from?
[memory]: And just who the hell are you, for that matter?
5 [memory]: First they tell me to go back into the Tardis, then they try to kill me. It doesn't make sense.
[memory]: What are you going to do now, Doctor?
[memory]: Temperon particle acceleration now reaching optimum reading. Prepare to engage vortex drive.
[memory]: It looks like space is folding in on itself.

6 [memory]: The distortion's increasing the closer we get. Caught in some ghastly experiment, which it then attempted to destroy. But because of the massive release of Temperon particles, it's moment of death was somehow frozen.
[memory]: The Knights of Velyshaa, you have set them free. Beware the Sirens of Time.
7: Time Lords. Knights of Velyshaa. The Sirens of Time?
5: And that girl. It was the same girl every time.
7: Yes!
6: Well, gentlemen, she's obviously not who she appeared to be. And whatever her real agenda is, it led to this.
5: The destruction of Gallifrey as we know it.
Energy pulses.
7: Sounds nastily familiar.
6: Vortex drive. The experiment on the Temperon.
5: The air's full of charged particles. Something's materialising.
6: I think we'd better make ourselves scarce.
7: Quick, over here. Argh, you're on my foot.
6: Well, shift up a bit. For someone so short, you're taking up a lot of room.
7: No comment.
5: Will you two keep quiet?
Energy pulses crescendo and fade.
6: Exactly the same as that ship in the Temperon experiment.
7: And as it told you, we set the Knights of Velyshaa free.
Door hisses open.
5: Here comes trouble.
6: Over there. Look.
Marching feet.
6: A touch of medizeval knight.
5: A touch of high-powered technology.
7: Either way, you wouldn't invite them round to dinner, would you?
Marching stops.
In the name of Sancroff, First Knight of the glorious Second Empire of Velyshaa, we welcome you back to Gallifrey, Knight Commander Lyena.
7: Sancroff?
5: Shh.
Is the Temperon back under restraint, Sub-Commander Solanec?
Yes, Knight Commander.
Increase power to the restraint field. If it happens again, I will have your head.
Yes, Knight

(furious) Is this what happens the moment I leave this cursd planet? Whole galaxies have fallen to the power of our Empire, but there is no work in all the universe more important than that which we do here. If our sacred mission on Gallifrey is jeopardised, Solanec, the Knights of Velyshaa will fall. But before that happens I will see you and every one of your Knights torn limb from limb, and your very lifeblood
Beeps.
What is that?
Knight Commander, we detect Time Lord lifesigns in the immediate vicinity.
Show me the readings.
7: Oh no.
5: They've detected us somehow.
How did they escape from the exploration compounds?
I
More incompetence!
6: Over to the left. Service ducts, remember?
7: Yes.
5: They lead to the vaults and foundations.
6: Come on!
They're there, Knight Commander.
Stop them!
6: Quickly!
Weapons fire.
5: It's a long way down.
7: And we don't know what's at the bottom.
6: We don't have a choice. Come on, jump!
7: Oh, argh!
They have escaped into the lower areas of the Capitol, Knight Commander.
Surprise me further, Solanec. Use weaponry on restraint settings. I want them found and brought to me alive.
Cries and coughing.
6: Are you all right?
5: I think I've broken something. What about you?
7: Yes, I'm fine, thanks.
6: I rather think I broke your fall.
7: Oh, sorry.
6: I'll survive.
5: Oh, can you two help me up?
6: Yes, okay.
7: Here, here.
5th Doctor cries in pain.
6: Careful, careful.
5: Oh, we're going to make a fine team with you two having to help me walk.
6: I do hope you're not going to be tediously noble and suggest we leave you down here.
5: The thought had crossed my mind.
7: Where are we going to to, anyway?
6: Isn't it obvious?
5: I suppose it is, really.
7: You mean find the Temperon.
6: They've obviously got it here somewhere.
7: Perhaps as the source of their time travel power.
5: Undoubtedly, I'd say.
6: Yes.
7: Yes, it's. Oh, sorry.
6: Sorry.
6+7: No, no, no, you. No, you.
7: No, you were there first anyway. Okay.
6: Anyway, I was going to say, from what we overheard it's evidently being kept here
against its will. Maybe if we find a way to set if free
5: I think that's a little rash at this stage. All we know for certain is that Gallifrey has been conquered by these Knights of Velyshaa, and the Temperon is involved somehow.
6: And so are we. Come on. There should be a lift around here somewhere.
7: Best foot forward, Doctors.
All of space and time. All of space and time was yours for the taking. And now all you will know for eternity is subjugation at the hands of the Velyshaan Empire. Lords of Time. Now Lords of nothing.
Door opens.
Knight Commander.
Your report, Solanec.
The fugitive Time Lords have been traced to an elevator ascending from the lower levels. My Knights are preparing to intercept it.
Good, good. How did they escape from the compounds?
They did not, Knight Commander.
Are you attempting to insult my intelligence?
Our, our readings indicate there is no match between their artron energy signatures and that of any of the captured Time Lords.
You mean they arrived here recently?
Perhaps, Knight Commander. There is something else.
Continue.
Our readings point to the fact that they are three incarnations of the same Time Lord.
Mmm, fascinating.
Door opens.
Don't move.
5: I'm afraid I couldn't if I tried.
Where are the others?
5: Sorry, I don't follow you. What others?
Falling rubble.
6: Careful. Take your foot out of my. Thank you.
7: Yes. (effort) Come on.
6: Ah, come on. Oh, right. Back in the Panopticon. Do you know, I think that was worse than climbing in the Himalayas.
7: Yes. Still, we made it.
6: Hmm. Now, the Temperon spoke to us telepathically, so
7: Agreed. Contact.
6: Contact.
Doctor. Doctor.
6: I think it gave me an impression of where it is.
7: Good. I don't do impressions.
6: Yes. Come on.
Door opens.
Ah, Doctor. Do sit down.
5: Thank you. I'm flattered you know my name.
Oh, we found Time Lord records to be meticulous in their accuracy. Where are your other selves?
5: Wandered off, I'm afraid. I really ought to keep more of a grip on myself.
They cannot escape us. You are the inferior species, Doctor.
6: I've got a feeling it's this way.
7: Yes. No, wait a minute.
6: What?
7: I've got a feeling too. What's going on in there?
Door opens.
6: Looks like they've converted it into a gigantic wardrobe for their suits of armour.
7: Yes. But what are these?
6: If I didn't know better, I'd say they were shower units. Perhaps this is the bathroom.
Door closes.
7: Watch out. Quick. I don't think it saw us.
6: I don't think it's aware of much at all. It seems to be in some difficulty.
Sub-Commander Solanec reporting for revitalisation.
Proceed with suit removal.
7: Maybe you were right about it being a bathroom.
6: Good grief. Look at its flesh.
7: Diseased, rotting.
6: Urgh.
Now entering revitalisation booth.
5: Ah!
There. The wound to your leg is now healed, Doctor.
5: Oh. Thank you.
Don't thank me. Thank your fellow Time Lords.
5: What do you mean?
Observe the screen.
5: Oh, no.
It is true that your people are now totally subjugated, but what we practice is subjugation with a distinct purpose.
Door opens.
7: So, the Knights of Velyshaa are far from being a healthy people.
6: Come on. This way. We have to find the Temperon.
7: In here?
6: In here.
7: You were right, Doctor.
6: I wish I hadn't been. What have they done to it?
7: Must be in the restraint field they mentioned.
Doctor.
Stay where you are.
7: What kind of people are you? What has this creature ever done to harm you?
6: You took from it the power to travel through time and space, and how do you repay it? By suspending it in torment?
Reporting to Knight Commander Lyena.
[OC]: Ah, I see you have found them. Bring them to the Time Chamber.
I have long waited for this moment, Doctors.
6: Flattery will get you nowhere.
5: What's so important about me as opposed to the rest of our people? I imagine you have the same fate in mind for us.
Three Time Lords for the price of one. Mmm, a tempting offer.
7: What does she mean?
Oh, please. Break the news to yourself.
5: It sickens me to even think of it.
6: What is it? What's happened to the Time Lords?
I believe you witnessed the revitalisation process, Doctor.
7: Revitalisation?
6: We saw a Knight without armour. Not a pretty sight.
We are all diseased, Doctor. The entire Velyshaan race, doomed. It may take millennia for us to die. We cheat death as best we can, but die we must.
5: So you're extracting the life force of Time Lords to stave off the inevitable.
7: You mean?
5: Death camps, or rather factories for the living dead. The Knights of Velyshaa have our entire race suspended in constant torment!
6: You seem to have a penchant for that kind of treatment with regard to species other than yourselves.
Oh, believe me, Doctor, we suffer our own agonies.
7: I was referring to the Temperon.
Ah yes, the Temperon. The creature for whom ones such as yourselves has much compassion. You see, Doctor, I know your nature. I feel I know you all so well.
6: What do you mean?
You're familiar with this chamber, I take it?
5: The Time Chamber?
7: Yes, we are.
When I was posted Garrison Commander of Gallifrey, this impressive piece of technology
6: The Time Chart?
Precisely. The Time Chart had all but been destroyed.
6; Ah.
But the decades have hung heavily on my shoulders. I needed a pastime, an amusement.
7: So you reactivated the Time Chart. Wasn't it enough that your people were already playing god with Time?
(laughs) Such moral indignation. Oh, you surpass my wildest dreams. I wasn't even sure that you would ever arrive here. Who would have thought that the Temperon would have been so obliging?
6: Would it be too much to ask you to get to the point?
Ah, the different facets of the same personality. Delightful. One is the thinker, one the compassionate, the other, impatient. And yet you all share these qualities too.
5: I assure you, it's far more complex than that.
6: What do you want of us?
In many ways you have already given the Knights of Velyshaa far more than they could have hoped for.
5: What do you mean?
7: Yes, do get on with it. I'm really getting rather bored with this.
Look at the Time Chart and your smugness will vanish, little man.
7: Sticks and stones.
Three nexus points in the continuum. Three. With one thing in common. You.
[OC]: A long time ago, my dear. A life time ago.
7 [OC]: There must be some way of talking to these ah! Hello, listen to me. We're here by accident, but perhaps
[OC]: Citizens of Calfador have no quarrel with you, but we regret there must be no witnesses.
And what happened next?
7: Since you're so clever, I thought

Very well. You found a way of using the planetary forcefield's power to repel the bio- assassins. Sancroff was saved from illegal execution at the hands of the Calfadorians, Saved to continue his life sentence. Saved so that we, the Valyshaans, could one day find and reclaim him to inspire a new campaign of conquest. Not so smug now, little man. The second nexus point. You weren't aware that while you were so frantic to get back to the Tardis, you were preventing the submarine craft U-20 from sinking the vessel known as the Lusitania.
[OC]: She's turning to starboard by about twenty to thirty degrees. The chart
5: The sinking of the Lusitania in 1915. It prompted the United States to declare war on Germany. You mean I changed the course of the first World War on Earth?
Oh, nothing so pedestrian. The war was largely unchanged. But do you know who this man is?
5: The face is familiar.
6: Alexander Fleming?
5: Discovered penicillin. Of course.

Murdered in December 1927, a few months before he might have made that discovery, and why? Because this man, Eric Charles Vincent, a petty criminal with psychotic tendencies, didn't die aboard the Lusitania as he should have done. He murdered Fleming in a bungled burglary. No penicillin, no antibiotics, no cure therefore for a mutated form of pneumonia and meningitis which ravaged planet Earth in 1956. The survivors never developed space travel, were never able to challenge and defeat the Knights of Velyshaa in the campaign of 3562.
5: But the Time Lords, they wanted me to return to the Tardis.
Oh, I think it's too late to blame anyone else. Now.
6: Let me guess. My turn. The Temperon.
[OC]: You must not succeed.

You were so close to the truth in this instance, Doctor. When I first reviewed this section, I felt sure that you would attempt to thwart us, and that our victory might be the fault of some other hapless fool. But no.
6: You mean I should have left the Temperon in torment, suspended at the moment of its death?
That had been the Temperon's choice.
6: What?

When our scientists attempted to extract temperon particles to activate our vortex drive ships, the Temperon elected self-destruction rather than help us to conquer Time. It rammed the prototype Velyshaan time ship.
6: Then I released it and made all this, this conquest, this suffering, possible?
5: We all did.
7: I take it you've enjoyed gloating?
It has been my last pleasure.
5: Why your last?

This chamber is sealed. No one can overhear this conversation. Now, listen to me, Doctors. There is a surviving Tardis here on Gallifrey. I want you to take it, travel back, and correct these, these mistakes.
6: But why? Without them, the Knights of Velyshaa
Would never have started the glorious Second Empire. There would have been only one glorious war, and then a clean final defeat, instead of this.
7: You mean the disease. How did that come about?
We call it the Curse of the Temperon.
5: Temperon? You mean it caused the disease?

Whether by design or mere chance. The temperon particles used in the vortex drive introduced a subtle but deadly mutation into the cells of all Valyshaans who used it. We discovered the truth far too late. We've drained the life force of whole galaxies to hold back our own extinction. Now only the Time Lords remain as suitable donors.
7: And one day even they will die out.

Our scientists strive to find a cure, experimenting on the Temperon to discover some vaccine or, but I know my heart it is fruitless. So, Doctors, you must save us from this destiny, this curse. I will escort you to the Tardis.
6: Ah, this is a Type 70. Very top of the range.
7: It's seen better days.
6: Well, we'd better get to work and keep her Majesty out there happy.
5: You know, all that nexus point business, it still doesn't explain the girl, Helen, Elenya, Ellie, why we couldn't get back into our Tardises, why we made those mistakes.
7: We thought we were making the right choices. We didn't.

5: I'm having difficulty accepting that. Each time, each of us was unable to re-enter the Tardis, even though, certainly in my case, the Time Lords apparently knew we were about to adversely affect the time lines. It all points to some other force manipulating us.
7: Beware the Sirens of Time. We've got to find out who they are and what they're up to.
6: Oh, blast.
5+7: What is it?
6: I'm afraid your discussion is a little academic. The time core of this Tardis is burnt out.
5: What!
